textRegions.text: There is a small mailbox here.
According to the first lecture, Java was the first compile-once, run anywhere language.
According to the first lecture, Java was the first compile-once, run anywhere language.
It wasn’t; it was beaten by sixteen years.
The Z-Machine was devised in 1979 by Infocom to run large programs on home computers
The Z-Machine was devised in 1979 by Infocom to run large programs on home computers
Like Java, their code was compiled to an intermediate “bytecode”
The Z-Machine was devised in 1979 by Infocom to run large programs on home computers
Like Java, their code was compiled to an intermediate “bytecode”
It supported many machines; the Amiga,  Apple II,  Atari ST, Commodore 64/128, Macintosh, MS-DOS, …
The print, new line and quit instructions from earlier are each “opcodes”
The print, new line and quit instructions from earlier are each “opcodes”
Machine code is a real pain to write.
Machine code is a real pain to write.
How can we make it easier?
How can we do this with the Z-Machine in assembly?
How can we do this with the Z-Machine in assembly?
Recursion: f(n) = f(n - 1) + f(n - 2) ∀ n ∈ Z+
How can we do this with the Z-Machine in assembly?
Recursion: f(n) = f(n - 1) + f(n - 2) ∀ n ∈ Z+

print : The 12th fibonacci number is call @fib 12 -> $stackprint_num $stacknew_linequitMETHOD fib n    jz n rfalse    je n 1 rtrue    sub n 1 -> $stack    call @fib $stack -> $stack    sub n 2 -> $stack    call @fib $stack -> $stack    add $stack $stack -> $stack    ret $stack
Recursion is inefficient for fib(n) in both time and space, but it’s a classic example of recursion
Recursion is inefficient for fib(n) in both time and space, but it’s a classic example of recursion

Implemented primarily in the ZMachine class
Primary methods: mainLoop, executeCycle and callOp
Frequent friends: store, branch, getVariable, setVariable, and more!

protected void mainLoop() throws ZError {    while(this.running) {        this.executeCycle();    }    this.io.outputComment("VM terminated. Executed " +
this.opcodesExecuted + " opcodes.");}

if((opcode & 0xC0) == 0xC0) {            format = OPCODE_FORMAT_VARIABLE;            if((opcode & 0x20) == 0) {                operandCount = 2;            } else {                reallyVariable = true;            }            opcode = opcode & 0x1F;        } else if((opcode & 0x80) == 0x80) {            format = OPCODE_FORMAT_SHORT;            if((opcode & 0x30) == 0x30) {                operandCount = 0;            } else {                operandTypes = new byte[1];                operandCount = 1;                if((opcode & 0x30) == 0) {                    operandTypes[0] = OPERAND_TYPE_LARGE;                } else if((opcode & 0x10) == 0x10) {                    operandTypes[0] = OPERAND_TYPE_SMALL;                } else if((opcode & 0x20) == 0x20) {                    operandTypes[0] = OPERAND_TYPE_VAR;                } else {                    throw new StoryError(String.format("Nonsense in ExecuteCycle! PC = %d, opcode = %d, OPERAND_FORMAT_SHORT",                            this.pc, opcode));                }            }            opcode = opcode & 0x0F;        } else {            format = OPCODE_FORMAT_LONG;            operandCount = 2;            operandTypes = new byte[2];            if((opcode & 0x40) == 0x40) {                operandTypes[0] = OPERAND_TYPE_VAR;            } else {                operandTypes[0] = OPERAND_TYPE_SMALL;            }            if((opcode & 0x20) == 0x20) {                operandTypes[1] = OPERAND_TYPE_VAR;            } else {                operandTypes[1] = OPERAND_TYPE_SMALL;            }            opcode = opcode & 0x1F;        }

        if(format == OPCODE_FORMAT_VARIABLE) {            this.pc++;            short bits = this.memory[this.pc];            operandTypes = new byte[4];            operandCount = 0;            for(int i = 0; i < 4; ++i) {                byte type = (byte)((bits >>> (3 - i) * 2) & 0x03);                if(type != OPERAND_TYPE_OMITTED) {                    operandCount++;                }                operandTypes[i] = type;            }        }

(You are not expected 
to be able to read this)
Inspects the first few bits of the opcode byte to determine the opcode type
Inspects the first few bits of the opcode byte to determine the opcode type
Uses this information to extract the actual opcode
Inspects the first few bits of the opcode byte to determine the opcode type
Uses this information to extract the actual opcode
The preamble is also used to determine the opcode types, which may require reading the next byte as well
Operand values are retrieved from memory and variables are dereferenced
Operand values are retrieved from memory and variables are dereferenced

int[] operands = new int[operandCount];for(int i = 0; i < operandCount; ++i) {    if(operandTypes[i] == OPERAND_TYPE_LARGE) {        operands[i] = this.unsignedNumber(this.pc + 1);        this.pc += 2;    } else if(operandTypes[i] == OPERAND_TYPE_SMALL) {        operands[i] = this.memory[++this.pc];    } else if(operandTypes[i] == OPERAND_TYPE_VAR) {        operands[i] = this.getVariable(this.memory[++this.pc]);    }}

Essentially just a large switch statement that dispatches operations to the relevant methods.

else if(argCount == 1) {    switch(op) {        case 0: this.op_jz(args[0]); break;        case 1: this.op_get_sibling(args[0]); break;        case 2: this.op_get_child(args[0]); break;        case 3: this.op_get_parent(args[0]); break;        case 4: this.op_get_prop_len(args[0]); break;        case 5: this.op_inc(args[0]); break;        case 6: this.op_dec(args[0]); break;        case 7: this.op_print_addr(args[0]); break;        // case 8 doesn't exist.        case 9: this.op_remove_obj(args[0]); break;        case 10: this.op_print_obj(args[0]); break;        case 11: this.op_ret(args[0]); break;        case 12: this.op_jump(args[0]); break;        case 13: this.op_print_paddr(args[0]); break;        case 14: this.op_load(args[0]); break;        case 15: this.op_not(args[0]); break;    }}

notes.slide-30: In stage two the values of the operands discovered in stage one are determined. If the operand is a “large constant”, two bytes are read and used as a single unsigned number. If the operand is a “small constant”, one byte is read and used as an unsigned number. If the operand was a variable, the variable number is pulled from one byte and resolved by getVariable. [space]
notes.slide-19: Like The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy, by Douglas Adams.[space]
notes.slide-27:
Much of the work is performed by executeCycle, [space] which is responsible for decoding and arranging for the execution of instructions. [space]
It first decodes the opcodes – that is, the instructions – and then resolves the operands to be passed to it. Finally, it calls callOp to actually make something happen. [space]
notes.slide-11: So let’s try a less trivial program, now that we have a more trivial language. For instance, [space] let’s find the twelfth Fibonacci number. [space] [space] How can we actually do this? [space] The classic approach – a recursive function. Any fibonacci number is the sum of the two previous fibonacci numbers, [space] with the first two being defined as being one. [space]
notes.slide-35: We can save the state of the machine itself! This makes the task much easier for the program, which [space] only has to call “save” or “restore” to save or load a game. At its core, all we have to do is [space] write the memory, stack and the program counter to a file, which we can later restore. Although the simplest solution would be to simply dump the memory, stack, call stack, stack pointer, call stack pointer and program counter to a file, that isn’t very portable, and this thing is all about portability. As such, we instead [space] write to a standardised save-game format called “Quetzal”, allowing other Quetzal-compliant interpreters to load our save files.[space]
notes.slide-16: A game! This is one of the earliest text-adventure games, and probably the best well known. [space]
notes.slide-6:
First off, “zero three” gives the version number of the file – three, in this case. [space]
The next ten digits are uninteresting header. [space]
Zero zero one zero – that is, sixteen – is the address at which to start execution. In this case it points immediately after the header. [space]
The next sixteen digits are more useless header [space]
notes.slide-24:
The separation of UI and logic has resulted in two user interfaces. [space]
TextIO was the first, and ZUI was only developed after the virtual machine itself functioned correctly. [space]
ZUI is a GUI built using Swing, while TextIO is a text interface, using only System.in and System.out for communication with the user.[space]
ZUI is, unsurprisingly, more complex than TextIO; [space] handling of input is notably harder. [space]
Both of these interfaces are present in ProjectZ; which one is loaded depends on which main method is called.
notes.slide-32: Here is an excerpt from callOp; specifically dealing with the case where a one-operand instruction has been called. As you can see, it simply calls the op method corresponding with the opcode it’s handed. [space]
notes.slide-29: [space] executeCycle first inspects the first few bits – how many varies – and then [space] trims the metadata out to find the actual opcode. [space] The first bits also tell it what sort of operands have been provided, or if the subsequent byte must be consulted to work this out. [space]
notes.slide-13: So does it work? [space] It does! [space] It is worth noting that this solution is not an efficient one, but it is the stereotypical example. [space] However, [space]
notes.slide-37:
So, [space] we can load, run, save and restore our programs. [space]
We can read input from the user, and display output to them. [space]
We can compute anything that is computable. [space]
We’re done! [space]
notes.slide-21: This was the first Z-Machine game not produced by Infocom; many more followed. [space]
notes.slide-5:
Machine code is, by definition, the most primitive computer language – it’s what is executed by the machine, with no translation (well, [space] you could use butterflies…)
(pause)
In any case, let’s take a look at what this string of numbers means… [space]
notes.slide-18: However, this is, despite being fairly specialised, still a general-purpose machine, so there are other games too… [space]
notes.slide-26:
The mainLoop, unsurprisingly, is simply a loop, [space] and is thus largely trivial.[space]
You can see here that it simply calls executeCycle as long as the machine is still running. It’s also responsible for the opcode count seen at the end of programs. [space]
notes.slide-10:
We can build an assembly language! [space]
Assembly is a step up from machine code, being [space] human readable, but can be (roughly) transliterated to machine code, without (much) actual translation. [space]
So what does this look like? [space] Something like this.
[space]
notes.slide-34:
So, thus far we’ve developed a virtual computer that can run our games.[space]
But we’re missing something: we haven’t given the games any filesystem access, [space] and you will never finish them in one sitting.[space]
How can we arrange for save games? [space]
notes.slide-4:
So, let’s take a look at a trivial program for this machine – “Hello, world!”
[space]
And there it is! The easiest to understand program you’ve ever seen.
[space]
Or perhaps not.
[space]
It’s a hexadecimal representation of the program written in machine code.
[space]
notes.slide-15: However, [space] nobody really cares what the twelfth Fibonacci number is; is there [space] anything else we can do? As suggested by parts of the UI earlier, [space] there are… [space]
notes.slide-23:
Since everyone loves UML, here is some that’s been trimmed to fit onto a single slide. As you can see, the user interface is largely distinct from the virtual machine itself, with the ZIO interface being the only way the ZMachine can communicate with the world. ZString and ZSCIIString both model internal data structures that the interpreter must manipulate directly.
All private methods, as well as exceptions and the Quetzal classes have been omitted in the name of brevity – ZMachine alone has over ninety private methods, including one for each opcode, and 25 properties. [space]
notes.slide-31:
The final primarily component of the VM’s execution cycle is the callOp method. [space]
It is called by executeCycle after the instruction and its operands have been completely decoded, [space] and it has the responsibility of dispatching the operands, if any, to the relevant method for that instruction. [space]
notes.slide-9:
So, where are we now? [space]
This is definitely portable, but [space] perhaps not actually useful. [space]
Writing machine code is a pain; anything requiring us to do so doesn’t really help us all that much. [space]
How should we fix this? [space]
notes.slide-28: As you can see, this is rather less trivial than mainLoop was. [space after transition finished]
notes.slide-12:
This is what the program might look like. We first print out what we’re doing, call the fib function and put the result on the stack, then print it out.
The fib function itself first checks if n is zero, and if so returns zero. If n is one, it returns one. Failing that, it calls itself with n - 1, calls itself with n - 2, and returns the sum of the two. [space]
notes.slide-36:
Quetzal stands for “Quetzal Unifies Efficiently The Z-Machine Archive Language”. [space]
More to the point, it’s also a south american bird. [space]
Although we could dump the entire memory, this would be somewhat wasteful and would result in including an entire copy of the game in each save file. Instead we store only the differences between the current memory and the original memory image.[space]
We then use run-length encoding to reduce the inevitable vast swathes of zeros by a factor of up to 127, so that our final save file is only around 1 kilobyte, instead of the 128 kilobytes it might be otherwise. [space]
Unfortunately, Quetzal is too complex to discuss in the time available. [space]
notes.slide-20:
Which, incidentally, you should all go read or listen to if you haven’t already.
Of course, Infocom weren’t the only ones to write these programs…
[space]
notes.slide-3:
The Z-Machine was created in 1979 by a company called Infocom (which consisted entirely of guys from MIT), in order to run programs they had written for a PDP-10 at MIT on the tiny home computers of the day.
[space]
Similar to Java, they achieved this by compiling their source to an intermediate bytecode, which would then be run by an interpreter on the user’s computer.
[space]
Being that the 1980s had a massive proliferation of incompatible machines, there were many versions of the interpreter written, including versions for the Amiga, Macintosh, and so on.
[space]
notes.slide-17: This is particularly true of the opening sequence,[space]
notes.slide-8:
So what does this program actually spit out? This! [space]
You may notice that it says [space] ‘executed three opcodes’ at the end. What’s that? [space]
The “print”, “new line” and “quit” instructions are three opcodes; [space] there are a total of 67 of them. [space]
notes.slide-25:
The virtual machine itself is implemented in the zmachine.ZMachine class.[space]
Execution consists primarily of mainLoop, executeCycle and callOp, the latter two of which are called once for every operation run.[space]
Further important methods include store, branch, and many others.[space]
Of course, the sixty-seven methods responsible for actually making things happen are important, too.[space]
notes.slide-33: There are many more methods; here you can see what they are and how often they’re used. The biggest two are branch, which is used by all flow-control instructions to jump elsewhere in the program, and store, which used by all instructions that return a value. The op star methods have been omitted; they’re each called once by callOp. [space]
notes.slide-2:
In the first lecture, Mark stated that the JVM was the first cross-platform virtual machine.
[space]
He was wrong; another one was produced in 1979, sixteen years before Java.
[space]
notes.slide-14:
Was that actually any simpler than writing directly in machine code? [space]
I think you can see quite clearly [space] that it was. I have colour coded the output from my assembler here; the long sequence of zeros is space to store global variables, and the colours not shown before are for types of code not used in “hello world”. [space]

(if asked: pink = function declaration, lavender = label reference, orange = branch instruction, light green = variable reference)
notes.slide-38: And that’s all we have time for. Does anyone have any questions?
notes.slide-22:
So how does this virtual machine actually work? [space]
It is, of course, written in Java. [space]
The assembler actually isn’t, but it’s not really the point of the exercise; I just tired of writing machine code. [space]
The code itself is split between two packages, called “zmachine” and “projectz”, which are responsible for the logic and the user interface, respectively. [space]
notes.slide-7:
Now we get to the part of the program that actually does stuff: [space]
“B2” is the code for the print operation; it will print the string that follows. [space]
The next twenty digits represent “Hello world”, in an arcane five-bits-per-character encoding. [space]
“BB” is the new line instruction, and finally [space]
“BA” terminates the program; if it were omitted, it would just crash here. [space]
